music.title: Learning Sounds
music.content: Music begins with sounds around us. Pupils will listen to clapping, tapping, birds singing, and other natural sounds. This helps them understand rhythm and tone. Music makes learning fun and helps children express joy.
music.takehome: 1. Clap and tap different rhythms with your family. 2. Listen for bird sounds in the morning. 3. Try singing your name in a song. 4. Play a simple drum with a bottle. 5. Share a favorite song with your class.
exercises: Make a sound using any object at home.
Draw a drum and color it.

rhymes.title: Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star
rhymes.content: Rhymes are short, fun songs that help memory and language. In this lesson, pupils will sing the famous rhyme 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star.' Rhymes teach rhythm, words, and imagination.
examples: How I wonder what you are ❓
rhymes.takehome: 1. Sing the rhyme before bed. 2. Act the rhyme with hand movements. 3. Teach the rhyme to a friend. 4. Draw a star while singing. 5. Sing softly, then loudly.
exercises: Point at the stars at night.

current-affairs.title: Weather Today
current-affairs.content: Children learn about daily weather (sunny, rainy, cloudy, windy). This builds awareness of their environment and helps them describe the world around them.
current-affairs.takehome: 1. Look outside and describe the weather. 2. Tell your parents if it’s hot or cold. 3. Draw today’s weather. 4. Dress properly for the weather. 5. Share in class tomorrow.
exercises: Say 'It is sunny' or 'It is rainy.'
Tell your friend the weather today.

yoruba.title: Ẹ Káàárọ̀ (Good Morning)
yoruba.content: Yoruba children learn greetings as a sign of respect. Morning greeting is 'Ẹ Káàárọ̀'. Afternoon is 'Ẹ Kásán'. Evening is 'Ẹ Kálẹ́'.
yoruba.takehome: 1. Greet your parents in Yoruba at home. 2. Teach a sibling the greetings. 3. Write them in your notebook. 4. Use them in the morning and evening. 5. Say them politely.
exercises: Draw the sun and write 'Ẹ Káàárọ̀'.

hausa.title: Ina kwana (Good Morning)
hausa.content: In Hausa, greetings are important for respect. 'Ina kwana' means good morning. 'Ina wuni' means good afternoon. 'Barka da yamma' means good evening.
hausa.takehome: 1. Say 'Ina kwana' in the morning. 2. Teach your friends. 3. Write greetings in Hausa. 4. Share them with parents. 5. Use greetings daily.
exercises: Match greetings to times of day.
Draw the sun and write 'Ina kwana'.

igbo.title: Ụtụtụ ọma (Good Morning)
igbo.content: In Igbo, greetings show kindness and culture. 'Ụtụtụ ọma' means good morning. 'Ehihie ọma' means good afternoon. 'Mgbede ọma' means good evening.
igbo.takehome: 1. Greet your parents in Igbo. 2. Write the greetings in your book. 3. Say them daily. 4. Teach someone else. 5. Smile when greeting.

arabic.title: السلام عليكم (As-salāmu ʿalaykum)
arabic.content: Arabic children learn to greet with peace. 'As-salāmu ʿalaykum' means 'Peace be upon you.' The reply is 'Wa ʿalaykumu s-salām'.
arabic.takehome: 1. Greet your parents in Arabic. 2. Teach a friend. 3. Write the greeting. 4. Practice reply. 5. Use every day.

swahili.title: Jambo (Hello)
swahili.content: Swahili is spoken in East Africa. The basic greeting is 'Jambo' meaning hello. Another common greeting is 'Habari' (How are you?).
swahili.takehome: 1. Say 'Jambo' every morning. 2. Greet your classmates. 3. Teach your parents. 4. Write greetings in your notebook. 5. Smile when saying it.
